ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Different perspectives, both secular and religious, on human free choice. A historical understanding of how philosophers argued for or against the existence of free will.

I was exposed to philosophers I have not yet read, especially on the more modern end, and when reading the traditional famous ones, we focused on specific aspects of their philosophy that expanded my understanding of their whole school of thought. We also read theology as philosophy, which was new to me and helpful to practice parsing theology of the more mystical elements and focusing on the content.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Stern is definitely this course's major strength. His lectures are amazing and follows a clear direction. His speaking style is lucid and clear, and he is able to summarize difficult passages from e.g. Hegel, Kant in a way that is intuitive and convincing. He is also very kind and answers all questions with care and precision.
Strengths: engaging lectures, great slideshow/visuals, caring instructor, clear feedback for papers

Strengths: the prof was adaptable and open to suggestions, the course was structured well (with both thematic and chronological axes), it was interesting to see our definitions and concepts develop across the course and change over time, the course was wrapped up well in the end, and there were plenty of secondary reading suggestions available!
Weaknesses: there could have been more student engagement, and it sometimes felt like some students did not prepare independently for each class and thus could not contribute productively, so the same few students always made all the comments.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Anyone interested in moral agency, normativity, and the interplay of will, the intellect, and the good should take this class.
Yes! But expect (positive) critiques on your work + not an easy A.

Yes! The notion (or presumption) of free will pervades metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics, and thus there is exposure to many different streams of thought (including theology and secular philosophy) in this course!

extras.title: PHIL 284 01 - Will, Agency, and Free Choice
